elements.content: The synthesis and determination of the crystal structures of eight mixed-ligand divalent coordination polymers based on 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL) and ancillary nitrogen ligands (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)­ethene, p-bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene, bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane, bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)­bis­(imidazole), namely, [Zn(L)2(p-bix)] n (1), [Zn3(L)6(bpp)] n (2), [Cd1.5(L)3(bpp)] n (3), [Ni(L)2(bpe)·H2O] n (4), [Co(L)2(p-bix)] n (5), [Co1.5(L)3(bpy)0.5] n (6), [Mn3(L)6(bpe)] n (7), and [Mn3(L)6(bbi)] n (8), have been reported. They were well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1–5 all exhibit three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structures based on interchain type II I···I halogen bond interactions, or hydrogen bonding and type I I···I contacts, respectively. Moreover, π···π interactions are found in the structure of 3. In compounds 6–8, similar two-dimensional (2D) metal–organic layers are expanded to 3D supramolecular structures based on type II I···I halogen bond interactions or type I I···I contacts, respectively. Our structural analyses promise to help demonstrate that organic iodine prefers type II I···I halogen bond interactions. In addition, it is of importance to evaluate the contributing role of I···I halogen bonds or I···I contacts in crystal structure packing. In addition, their thermal analysis, X-ray powder diffraction, and UV–vis absorption spectra have been investigated as well.

They were well characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1-5 all exhibit three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structures based on interchain type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bond interactions, or hydrogen bonding and type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts, respectively. Moreover, π⋅⋅⋅π interactions are found in the structure of 3. In compounds 6-8, similar two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic layers are expanded to 3D supramolecular structures based on type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bond interactions or type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts, respectively. Our structural analyses promise to help demonstrate that organic iodine prefers type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bond interactions. In addition, it is of importance to evaluate the contributing role of I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds or I⋅⋅⋅I contacts in crystal structure packing. In addition, their thermal analysis, X-ray powder diffraction, and UV-vis absorption spectra have been investigated as well.

elements.content:
Halogen−halogen-driven self-assembly of divalent metal centers, 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid with ancillary nitrogen ligands gives rise to diverse extended networks in the crystalline state.

Introduction

Halogen bonding interactions have become an increasingly popular field of research over the past few decades, owing to instrumental roles in the assembly of diverse intriguing structures and promise in applications such as catalysis, medicinal chemistry, and molecular recognition processes. Among them, halogen–halogen interactions have been broadly defined as resulting from the polarization and dispersion/repulsion interactions of halogen atoms in the crystalline state. Desiraju and co-workers have used halogen atom interactions as design elements in crystal engineering for nearly 30 years and stated that halogen bonding interactions include many halogen···halogen interactions (X···X) and almost all halogen···heteroatom interactions (X···B). Halogen···halogen interactions can be described in general as C–X1···X2–C, which are characterized in terms of three parameters, and two angles θ1 = C–X1···X2 and θ2 = X1···X2–C (θ1= θ2 for type I, and θ1 ≈ 180° and θ2 ≈ 90° for type II). In Desiraju’s recent account, the following criteria for classification of type I and type II contacts are suggested: (1) contacts with 0° ≤ |θ1 – θ2| ≤ 15° are type I; (2) contacts with 30° ≤ |θ1 – θ2| are type II; (3) contacts with 15° ≤ |θ1 – θ2| ≤ 30° are quasi-type I/type II. Moreover, Desiraju demonstrated that type I is a geometry-based contact that arises from close packing and is found for all halogens, while type II arises from an electrophile-nucleophile pairing, with only type II being true halogen bonds.

Halogen-halogen-driven self-assembly of divalent metal centers, 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid with ancillary nitrogen ligands gives rise to diverse extended networks in the crystalline state.

Introduction

Halogen bonding interactions have become an increasingly popular field of research over the past few decades, owing to instrumental roles in the assembly of diverse intriguing structures and promise in applications such as catalysis, medicinal chemistry, and molecular recognition processes. Among them, halogen-halogen interactions have been broadly defined as resulting from the polarization and dispersion/repulsion interactions of halogen atoms in the crystalline state. Desiraju and co-workers have used halogen atom interactions as design elements in crystal engineering for nearly 30 years and stated that halogen bonding interactions include many halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions (X⋅⋅⋅X) and almost all halogen⋅⋅⋅heteroatom interactions (X⋅⋅⋅B). Halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions can be described in general as C-X1⋅⋅⋅X2-C, which are characterized in terms of three parameters, and two angles θ1 = C-X1⋅⋅⋅X2 and θ2 = X1⋅⋅⋅X2-C (θ1= θ2 for type I, and θ1 ~ 180° and θ2 ~ 90° for type II). In Desiraju's recent account, the following criteria for classification of type I and type II contacts are suggested: (1) contacts with 0° ≤ |θ1 - θ2| ≤ 15° are type I; (2) contacts with 30° ≤ |θ1 - θ2| are type II; (3) contacts with 15° ≤ |θ1 - θ2| ≤ 30° are quasi-type I/type II. Moreover, Desiraju demonstrated that type I is a geometry-based contact that arises from close packing and is found for all halogens, while type II arises from an electrophile-nucleophile pairing, with only type II being true halogen bonds.

elements.content: Halogen bonding interactions have been recently exploited as a significant tool for engineering supramolecular systems. However, the presence of halogen bonding in metal coordination polymers especially high-dimensional coordination polymers remains largely unexplored and needs more elaborate and systematic studies. More recently, we have challenged the preparation of supramolecular complexes based on the rigid ligand 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-H2iipa) to investigate the role of halogen-related bonding in the assembly of coordination polymers. The preliminary work shows that solvent molecules and N-donor auxiliary ligands are effective methods in constructing coordination polymers with diverse architectures.

However, the presence of halogen bonding in metal coordination polymers especially high-dimensional coordination polymers remains largely unexplored and needs more elaborate and systematic studies. More recently, we have challenged the preparation of supramolecular complexes based on the rigid ligand 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-H2iipa) to investigate the role of halogen-related bonding in the assembly of coordination polymers. The preliminary work shows that solvent molecules and N-donor auxiliary ligands are effective methods in constructing coordination polymers with diverse architectures.

elements.content: To extend our previous work, and, at the same time, to attempt assembly of high-dimensional supramolecular coordination architectures based on halogen···halogen interactions, we designed and synthesized a new ligand 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL). Compared to 5-iipa, the HL ligand possesses two iodine atoms which can more easily introduce I···I interaction into coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: To extend our previous work, and, at the same time, to attempt assembly of high-dimensional supramolecular coordination architectures based on halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions, we designed and synthesized a new ligand 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL). Compared to 5-iipa, the HL ligand possesses two iodine atoms which can more easily introduce I⋅⋅⋅I interaction into coordination polymers.

elements.content: In this paper, a series of eight supramolecular complexes assembled by 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid and N-donor ligands (4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)­ethane (bpe), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (p-bix), 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane (bpp), 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)­bis(imidazole) (bbi)) were isolated under hydrothermal conditions. Herein, the structures of these compounds along with the influence of synthetic parameters on the structures are presented in detail. I···I interactions have been found in all the structures 1–8, and such interactions play vital roles in the assembly of high-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers.

Herein, the structures of these compounds along with the influence of synthetic parameters on the structures are presented in detail. I⋅⋅⋅I interactions have been found in all the structures 1-8, and such interactions play vital roles in the assembly of high-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers.

elements.content: 3,5-Diiodobenzoic acid was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm–1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for 1–8 was measured at 293 K on a Rigaku D/Max-2500PC diffractometer (Cu–Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). The crushed single crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanned from 5 to 50 °C with a step of 0.1°/s. Solid UV–visible spectra were obtained in the 200–800 nm range on a JASCO UVIDEC-660 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

3,5-Diiodobenzoic acid was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm-1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for 1-8 was measured at 293 K on a Rigaku D/Max-2500PC diffractometer (Cu-Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). The crushed single crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanned from 5 to 50 °C with a step of 0.1°/s. Solid UV-visible spectra were obtained in the 200-800 nm range on a JASCO UVIDEC-660 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Complex 1 was synthesized solvothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (0.0112 g, 0.03 mmol), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (p-bix) (0.0071 g, 0.03 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0089 g, 0.03 mmol), NaOH (0.0012 g, 0.03 mmol), and 1 mL of methanol in 6 mL of distilled water at 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Subsequent cooling to room temperature yielded colorless block crystals of 1 (75% yield based on zinc). Anal. Calc. for C28H20I4N4O4Zn (1049.45): C, 32.04; H, 1.92; N, 5.34%. Found: C, 32.09; H, 1.96; N. 5.28%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3437 (m), 3112 (m), 1605 (s), 1532 (vs), 1417 (m), 1359 (s), 1247 (m), 1107 (s), 785(m), 721 (m), 653 (w).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of compounds 1–8 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the intensities using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using the program SHELXS-97 and refined with the program SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the solvent water molecules were located from the difference Fourier maps, then restrained at fixed positions, and refined isotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data, selected bond lengths, and angles for HL and 1–8 are listed in Tables and .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of compounds 1-8 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the intensities using the SADABS program. The structures were solved using the program SHELXS-97 and refined with the program SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the solvent water molecules were located from the difference Fourier maps, then restrained at fixed positions, and refined isotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data, selected bond lengths, and angles for HL and 1-8 are listed in Tables  and .

As a starting point for our discussion on the preparation of divalent coordination polymers based on 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL) and ancillary nitrogen ligands, we present X-ray studies of the HL ligand first. A single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that adjacent HL molecules are connected by O2–H1···O1#1 and O2#1–H1#1···O1 (O2–O1#1 2.650 Å) hydrogen bonds to form the double molecular structure. Similar to 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-iipa) in our recent work, I···O halogen bonding (3.183 Å) also exists, which linked adjacent double molecules to a wave-like supramolecular layer, as shown in Figure a. Finally, association of layers through face-to-face weak π···π stacking interactions between adjacent phenyl rings (intercentroid distance: 4.221 Å) leads to a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure b). The shortest I···I distance between the I atom of adjacent layers is 4.139 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

3,5-Diiodobenzoic acid (HL)

As a starting point for our discussion on the preparation of divalent coordination polymers based on 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL) and ancillary nitrogen ligands, we present X-ray studies of the HL ligand first. A single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that adjacent HL molecules are connected by O2-H1⋅⋅⋅O1#1 and O2#1-H1#1⋅⋅⋅O1 (O2-O1#1 2.650 Å) hydrogen bonds to form the double molecular structure. Similar to 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-iipa) in our recent work, I⋅⋅⋅O halogen bonding (3.183 Å) also exists, which linked adjacent double molecules to a wave-like supramolecular layer, as shown in Figure a. Finally, association of layers through face-to-face weak π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between adjacent phenyl rings (intercentroid distance: 4.221 Å) leads to a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure b). The shortest I⋅⋅⋅I distance between the I atom of adjacent layers is 4.139 Å.

elements.content: To date, it is well-known that ancillary ligands can be applied as effective tectons for constructing diverse coordination networks with desired strcutural features. In order to study the effect of ancillary ligands on the final structures and halogen···halogen interactions, herein we select five kinds of ancillary nitrogen ligands to assemble of divalent metal–organic supramolecular frameworks based on 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL).
elements.clean_text: To date, it is well-known that ancillary ligands can be applied as effective tectons for constructing diverse coordination networks with desired strcutural features. In order to study the effect of ancillary ligands on the final structures and halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen interactions, herein we select five kinds of ancillary nitrogen ligands to assemble of divalent metal-organic supramolecular frameworks based on 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the P21 /c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1, shown in Figure a, is composed of one crystallographically independent Zn(II) center, two L– ligands, and one p-bix ligand. The Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3) from two L– ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two p-bix ligands to achieve a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. The Zn–O lengths are 1.981(4) and 2.002(4) Å, and the Zn1–N1 and Zn1–N4#1 lengths are 1.993(4) and 2.032(5) Å, respectively. Each completely deprotonated L– ligand coordinates to the Zn(II) center with the carboxyl group in a monodentate coordination mode. Adjacent Zn(II) centers are bridged by p-bix ligands with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of 56.275° to form an infinite zigzag chain along the c axis (Figure b). Such chains are hierarchically entangled to produce a layer structure by weak I···I interactions (4.013 Å, 97% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 148.1°), which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (4.12 Å), as illustrated in Figure c. Then, adjacent layers are further organized together via I···I interactions (4.045 Å, 98% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 151.5°) to form the 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: To investigate the effect of coexisting ligands on the assembly of resulting structures, we introduced bpp into the Zn/L system and obtained a new supramolecular architecture. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of three crystallographically independent Zn(II) atoms, six L– anions, and one bpp ligand. As depicted in Figure , there are two types of coordination environments around the Zn(II) ions. Both Zn1 and Zn3 show tetrahedral geometries. Zn1 is four-coordinated to three carboxylate O atoms (O1, O3, O5) from three L– anions and one N atom (N1) from one bpp ligand, while Zn3 center is tetrahedrally surrounded by O8, O9, and O12 atoms from three different L– anions and N2#1 atoms from the bpp ligand. Zn2 sits in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry and six-coordinated to six carboxylate oxygen atoms from six crystallographically nonequivalent L– ligands. The Zn–O bond distances are in the range of 1.909–2.243 Å, and the Zn1–N1 and Zn3–N2#1 bond distances are 2.033 and 2.001 Å, respectively. The bond angles around the Zn(II) atom range from 87 to 174.1°. The carboxylate groups of L– ligands in 2 exhibit three kinds of coordination modes: one in a μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode, one μ2-η1:η1 bridging mode, and another one in a μ2-η2:η1 fashion. The bpp ligands link neighboring trinuclear zinc clusters and six L– anions to yield an infinite chain along the c axis direction. Two adjacent 1D chains are interconnected through I···I interactions with the distance of adjacent I atoms from two different L– anions of 3.748 Å (91% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 164.1°), to form a 1D double chain (Figure b). It is interesting that each double chain interacts with two neighboring ones via weak I···I interactions (3.936 Å, 95% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 156.4°), further extending into a 2D layer structure. More interestingly, adjacent layers are first associated together through I···I halogen bonds between adjacent I atoms from two different layers to lead to a double layer structure, as depicted in Figure c. Then, such adjacent double layers are further organized together by weak I···I interactions (4.067 Å, 99% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 145.5°) to form the 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallized in monoclinic space group C2/c. Its framework is neutral with the asymmetric unit consisting of one and a half Cd(II) cations, three L– ligands, and one bpp ligand. Cd2 atom was refined with an occupancy factor of 0.5. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 center is seven-coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three L– anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different bpp ligands, displaying a slightly distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry with N1 and O2 atoms located at the apical position. Cd2 center displays an octahedral geometry, which is provided by six oxygen atoms from six L– anions. It is interesting to notice that the three pairs of oxygen atoms, namely, O1 and O1#2, O4 and O4#2, as well as O5 and O5#2, are symmetrical. The axial O5–Cd2–O5#2 angle and the angles around cadmium atom in the equatorial planes of O1–Cd2–O1#2, O4#2–Cd2–O4 are all 180.0°. However, the Cd2–O lengths vary from 2.191(5) to 2.390(5) Å, indicating an appreciable distortion from the ideal octahedral symmetry. Three Cd(II) atoms (Cd1, Cd2, Cd1#2) are linked by carboxyl groups of six L– ligands to form a Cd3 subunit (Figure b). Two bpp ligands bridged adjacent Cd3 clusters to form infinite ladder chain. This assembly is reinforced by face-to-face π···π stacking interactions between adjacent phenyl rings of L– anions with centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.475 and 3.597 Å, respectively (Figure c). Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the distance between iodine atoms of L– ligands from adjacent chains is 3.766 Å (91% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 177.2°), which is indicative of the existence of weak I···I interaction. As illustrated in Figure d, adjacent chains from different directions are combined by such I···I interactions to give rise to a 3D supramolecular network.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 4 consists of one Ni(II) ion, one bpe ligand, two L– ligand, and one guest water molecule. As depicted in Figure a, the Ni1 ion possesses a distorted octahedral geometry which is completed by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1–O4) from two different L– anions and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N2) from two different bpe ligands. Four atoms O2, O3, O4, and N1 comprise the equatorial plane, while O1 and N2 occupy the apical positions with the O1–Ni1–N2 angle being 163.9°. The Ni1–O bond lengths range from 2.084 to 2.129 Å, and the Ni1–N1 and Ni1–N2 bond distances are 2.044 and 2.028 Å. All the Ni–O and Ni–N bond distances are within the range reported for Ni(II)-based coordination polymers. Neighboring Ni(II) atoms are linked by bpe ligands to yield an infinite 1D (Ni-bpe) n chain (Figure b). As shown in Figure c, hydrogen bonds between free water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1W#1–H1WA#1···O2, O1W#1–O2 2.750 Å, O1W#2–H1WB···O3, O1W#2–O3 2.812 Å) link two neighboring (Ni-bpe) n chains to give rise to a 2D layer. Additional investigation for this structure indicates that the 2D layers are extended to a 3D supramolecular structure by weak I···I interactions with the distance of adjacent I atoms from two different layers of 3.976 Å (96% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 167.5°), as depicted in Figure d.

elements.content: Compounds 6–8 have similar 2D layer structures and exhibit 3D supramolecular networks through interlayer I···I interactions. Therefore, compound 6 is employed as a representative structure to be described in detail. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 6 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit of 6 consists of one and a half Co(II) centers, three L– ligands, and half a bpy ligand. Co2 atom was refined with an occupancy factor of 0.5. Co1 and Co2 centers display different coordination geometries. Co1 is surrounded by two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups, two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η2 carboxylate groups, and one nitrogen atom from bpy ligand to form a trigonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry, whereas Co2 coordinates to four oxygen atoms from four different μ2-η1:η1 carboxylates groups, and two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η2 carboxylate groups to produce an octahedral coordination geometry. The Co–O bonds possess an average distance of ∼2.074 Å, which is consistent with the reported values. As illustrated in Figure b, one Co2 atom is linked with two Co1 atoms via carboxylate bridges to form trinuclear clusters (Co1–Co2 is 3.348 Å). As illustrated in Figure b,c, adjacent trinuclear clusters were bridged by the carboxylate group (O3–O4) and their symmetry-related molecules to assemble into an infinite chain, and such chains are further linked by bpy ligands running along the b-axis to furnish a 2D layer in the ab plane. The distance between the adjacent iodine atoms of neighboring layers is 4.000 Å (97% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 154.2°), shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (4.12 Å), which indicates there are weak I···I interactions. Adjacent layers are associated through such weak I···I interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure d).

Therefore, compound 6 is employed as a representative structure to be described in detail. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 6 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit of 6 consists of one and a half Co(II) centers, three L- ligands, and half a bpy ligand. Co2 atom was refined with an occupancy factor of 0.5. Co1 and Co2 centers display different coordination geometries. Co1 is surrounded by two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate groups, two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η2 carboxylate groups, and one nitrogen atom from bpy ligand to form a trigonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry, whereas Co2 coordinates to four oxygen atoms from four different μ2-η1:η1 carboxylates groups, and two oxygen atoms from two different μ2-η1:η2 carboxylate groups to produce an octahedral coordination geometry. The Co-O bonds possess an average distance of ~2.074 Å, which is consistent with the reported values. As illustrated in Figure b, one Co2 atom is linked with two Co1 atoms via carboxylate bridges to form trinuclear clusters (Co1-Co2 is 3.348 Å). As illustrated in Figure b,c, adjacent trinuclear clusters were bridged by the carboxylate group (O3-O4) and their symmetry-related molecules to assemble into an infinite chain, and such chains are further linked by bpy ligands running along the b-axis to furnish a 2D layer in the ab plane. The distance between the adjacent iodine atoms of neighboring layers is 4.000 Å (97% of Σr vdW; ∠C-I⋅⋅⋅I: 154.2°), shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (4.12 Å), which indicates there are weak I⋅⋅⋅I interactions. elements.content: The structures of compounds 7 and 8 are similar to that of 6, but there are little differences among them (Figure ). On one hand, the coordination numbers of metal atoms are different. In compound 6, the metal centers display distorted trigonal-bipyramidal and octahedral coordination geometries, while distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal and octahedral environment are seen in compounds 7 and 8. On the other hand, the distances of I···I halogen-related bonding are different. In 7 and 8, the distances between the adjacent I atoms are 3.960 and 3.965 Å (96% of Σr vdW; ∠C–I···I: 141.9° and 138.2°), respectively, which differ from a distance of 4.000 Å in 6.

elements.content: Because the mixing of metal salts and organic ligands solutions usually results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, making it difficult to grow crystals of complexes, hydrothermal methods were adopted in our studies, and these methods have been extensively explored as an effective and powerful tool in the assembly of coordination polymers for the preparation of sparingly soluble inorganic–organic hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Effects of the Synthetic Conditions on the Structures of Coordination Assemblies

Because the mixing of metal salts and organic ligands solutions usually results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, making it difficult to grow crystals of complexes, hydrothermal methods were adopted in our studies, and these methods have been extensively explored as an effective and powerful tool in the assembly of coordination polymers for the preparation of sparingly soluble inorganic-organic hybrid materials.

elements.content: To obtain structural data that unambiguously could test our hypothesis regarding halogen-bond preferences, we carried out numerous parallel experiments by changing the reaction temperatures from 120 to 160 °C, and varying the reaction time (2–5 days) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. However, only eight X-ray suitable crystals were obtained. Only precipitates are obtained in other reactions conditions (reaction temperature and time).

However, only eight X-ray suitable crystals were obtained. Only precipitates are obtained in other reactions conditions (reaction temperature and time).

elements.content: In this work, we selected five kinds of ancillary nitrogen ligands (p-bix, bbi, bpy, bpe, bpp) to observe their effects on the assembly of coordination polymers. From the structural descriptions above, it can be seen that the neutral ligands have great influences on the frameworks of complexes. In complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6, the neutral ligands display bridging coordination modes with two N atoms coordinating to two different metal ions, and the linkers with different flexibilities play important roles in affecting the final structures. Compared with bpp, the two imidazole rings of p-bix can freely twist around the −CH2– group to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries of metal atoms in the assembly process. In 1, p-bix ligands bridge neighboring Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite zigzag chain. These chains are further entangled to lead to a layer structure by weak I···I interactions. elements.clean_text:
Effects of the Ancillary Nitrogen Ligands and the Central Metals on the Structures of the Compounds

In this work, we selected five kinds of ancillary nitrogen ligands (p-bix, bbi, bpy, bpe, bpp) to observe their effects on the assembly of coordination polymers. From the structural descriptions above, it can be seen that the neutral ligands have great influences on the frameworks of complexes. In complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6, the neutral ligands display bridging coordination modes with two N atoms coordinating to two different metal ions, and the linkers with different flexibilities play important roles in affecting the final structures. Compared with bpp, the two imidazole rings of p-bix can freely twist around the -CH2- group to meet the requirements of the coordination geometries of metal atoms in the assembly process. In 1, p-bix ligands bridge neighboring Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite zigzag chain. These chains are further entangled to lead to a layer structure by weak I⋅⋅⋅I interactions. However, in 2, bpp ligands link neighboring trinuclear zinc clusters to yield an infinite linear chain. Adjacent linear chains are interconnected through I⋅⋅⋅I interactions to form a 1D double chain, double layer structure, and finally 3D supramolecular architecture. The effect of ancillary nitrogen ligand is further supported by compounds 5 and 6.

elements.content: On the other hand, the central metals have significant effects on the resultant supramolecular structures. For example, compounds 4 and 7 show the effect of the central metals on the final structures. In 4, bpe ligands bridge adjacent Ni(II) atoms to form an infinite zigzag chain. Then, the (Ni-bpe) n chains are associated together through hydrogen bonds to give rise to 2D layer, and finally extended to 3D supramolecular structure through weak I···I interactions. However, in 7, there are trinuclear manganese clusters, and such clusters were associated together through the carboxylate groups to assemble into an infinite chain. Then, these chains are further linked by bpe ligands to give rise to a layer structure. Adjacent layers are associated through weak I···I interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular architecture. The differences in the coordination environments and coordination numbers of the central metals are the main factor that led to the difference in the structures of 2 and 3, as well as 7 and one previous work [Mn4(5-iipa)4­(bpe)4­·5H2O] n . In complexes 2 and 3, similar trinuclear metal clusters are found, but their coordination environments and coordination numbers are different. In 2, the central Zn(II) cations are four- [O3N1], and six-coordinated [O6], while in 3, the central Cd(II) cations are six- [O6], and seven-coordinated [O5N2], respectively. In 2, trinuclear zinc clusters connect two bpp ligands to form a linear chain, which finally through I···I interactions forms a 1D double chain, double layer structure, and 3D supramolecular architecture. In 3, trinuclear cadmium clusters link four bpp ligands to form 1D ladder-like chains, which are further linked by I···I interactions to form a 3D supramolecular architecture. Although I···I interactions appear in complexes 7 and one previous work [Mn4(5-iipa)4(bpe)4·5H2O] n , they show completely different resultant structures. In 7, trinuclear manganese clusters that can coordinate to much more 3,5-diiodobenzoic acids minimize the open channels and avoid interpenetration. Clearly, the structural differences between these compounds may be attributed to the difference in the coordination environments of the central metals.

elements.content: The reaction of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid with ancillary nitrogen ligands has been used to prepare a series of divalent coordination polymers. As expected, in all of the structures presented herein a common structural arrangement is present: the propensity to form high-dimensional supramolecular architectures through type II I···I halogen bonds interaction or type I I···I contacts is explored through introducing of two iodine atoms to the ligand. According to Desiraju’s criteria for classification, it is clear from Table that in six of the compounds (1–6) type II I···I halogen bonds are formed, while the remaining two compounds exhibit type I I···I contacts. There is a higher propensity for the formation of type II I···I halogen bonds in comparison to type I I···I contacts. The I···I interactions in the present study are all significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii (91–99% of Σr vdW, ∠C–I···I: 132.6–177.2°). In those cases, type I interactions are prominent at short distances, while type II is more frequently closer to vdW. This is because the electrostatic nature of type II contacts allows them to be viable at longer distances, whereas type I contacts being vdW operate at short distances. However, at separations greater than vdW, type I is again favored. Moreover, hydrogen bonding and π···π interactions also play instrumental roles in the assembly of coordination polymers with an increase in dimensionality as well as the stability.
elements.clean_text:
The I⋅⋅⋅I Halogen Bonds in the Supramolecular Coordination Polymers

The reaction of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid with ancillary nitrogen ligands has been used to prepare a series of divalent coordination polymers. As expected, in all of the structures presented herein a common structural arrangement is present: the propensity to form high-dimensional supramolecular architectures through type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds interaction or type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts is explored through introducing of two iodine atoms to the ligand. According to Desiraju's criteria for classification, it is clear from Table  that in six of the compounds (1-6) type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds are formed, while the remaining two compounds exhibit type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts. There is a higher propensity for the formation of type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds in comparison to type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts. The I⋅⋅⋅I interactions in the present study are all significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii (91-99% of Σr vdW, ∠C-I⋅⋅⋅I: 132.6-177.2°). In those cases, type I interactions are prominent at short distances, while type II is more frequently closer to vdW. This is because the electrostatic nature of type II contacts allows them to be viable at longer distances, whereas type I contacts being vdW operate at short distances. However, at separations greater than vdW, type I is again favored. Moreover, hydrogen bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions also play instrumental roles in the assembly of coordination polymers with an increase in dimensionality as well as the stability.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1–8 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1–8 are shown in . For compound 1, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 337 °C. For compounds 2 and 3, the framework collapsed from 340 and 302 °C, respectively. The TG curve of 4 shows that this complex loses its free water molecule between 33 to 128 °C (observed, 1.74%; calculated, 1.79%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 268 °C. For compound 5, the framework collapsed from 329 °C. For compound 6, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 400 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. In the case of compound 7, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 416 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG analysis for crystal samples of 8 shows the framework collapsed from 338 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis and X-ray Powder Diffraction

Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1-8 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1-8 are shown in . For compound 1, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 337 °C. For compounds 2 and 3, the framework collapsed from 340 and 302 °C, respectively. The TG curve of 4 shows that this complex loses its free water molecule between 33 to 128 °C (observed, 1.74%; calculated, 1.79%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 268 °C. For compound 5, the framework collapsed from 329 °C. For compound 6, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 400 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. In the case of compound 7, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 416 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG analysis for crystal samples of 8 shows the framework collapsed from 338 °C.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to check the purity of compounds 1–8. As shown in , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns (b) are similar to those in the simulated patterns (a) generated from single-crystal diffraction data, indicating single phases of 1–8 are formed. Since compound 5 is isostructural with 1, all the peaks in 5 basically agree with that in 1.

elements.content: The solid-state UV/vis spectra of HL and coordination polymers 1–8 are displayed in . The HL ligand itself displays weak absorption bands at 282 nm with a weak shoulder band at 327 nm, arising from the π–π* transition of the aromatic rings. These bands are not strongly perturbed upon its coordination to zinc(II), cadmium(II), nickel(II), cobalt(II), and manganese(II), suggesting that coordination of the metal ions hardly alters the intrinsic electronic properties of the ligand. For compounds 4, the additional band at ca. 584 nm probably originates from d–d spin-forbidden transition of the Ni(II) center. The absorptions of 5 and 6 in the visible region are observed at ca. 549 nm, which may result from the d–d spin-allowed transition of the d7 (Co2+) ion. The difference in the UV/vis absorption properties can be attributed to a discrepancy in the central metal atoms of the crystals.
elements.clean_text:
UV/vis Absorbance Properties

The solid-state UV/vis spectra of HL and coordination polymers 1-8 are displayed in . The HL ligand itself displays weak absorption bands at 282 nm with a weak shoulder band at 327 nm, arising from the π-π* transition of the aromatic rings. These bands are not strongly perturbed upon its coordination to zinc(II), cadmium(II), nickel(II), cobalt(II), and manganese(II), suggesting that coordination of the metal ions hardly alters the intrinsic electronic properties of the ligand. For compounds 4, the additional band at ca. 584 nm probably originates from d-d spin-forbidden transition of the Ni(II) center. The absorptions of 5 and 6 in the visible region are observed at ca. 549 nm, which may result from the d-d spin-allowed transition of the d7 (Co2+) ion. The difference in the UV/vis absorption properties can be attributed to a discrepancy in the central metal atoms of the crystals.

elements.content: High-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers 1–8 are successfully constructed by 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL) and ancillary nitrogen ligands based on type II I···I halogen bonds and/or type I I···I contacts. The crystal structures of these compounds highlight the propensity of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid to form extended halogen-bonded networks. The results also revealed that 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid is an effective ligand, which is useful to control the assembly of metal centers and potentially capable of partaking in I···I interaction. Accordingly, we believe that our present findings will enrich the crystal engineering strategies and offer the possibility of controlling preparation of such desired network-based solids, and I···I interactions must be considered as design elements in crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

High-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers 1-8 are successfully constructed by 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (HL) and ancillary nitrogen ligands based on type II I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds and/or type I I⋅⋅⋅I contacts. The crystal structures of these compounds highlight the propensity of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid to form extended halogen-bonded networks. The results also revealed that 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid is an effective ligand, which is useful to control the assembly of metal centers and potentially capable of partaking in I⋅⋅⋅I interaction. Accordingly, we believe that our present findings will enrich the crystal engineering strategies and offer the possibility of controlling preparation of such desired network-based solids, and I⋅⋅⋅I interactions must be considered as design elements in crystal engineering.

Complex 1 was synthesized solvothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (0.0112 g, 0.03 mmol), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (p-bix) (0.0071 g, 0.03 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0089 g, 0.03 mmol), NaOH (0.0012 g, 0.03 mmol), and 1 mL of methanol in 6 mL of distilled water at 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Subsequent cooling to room temperature yielded colorless block crystals of 1 (75% yield based on zinc). Anal. Calc. for C28H20I4N4O4Zn (1049.45): C, 32.04; H, 1.92; N, 5.34%. Found: C, 32.09; H, 1.96; N. 5.28%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3437 (m), 3112 (m), 1605 (s), 1532 (vs), 1417 (m), 1359 (s), 1247 (m), 1107 (s), 785(m), 721 (m), 653 (w).

Syntheses. [Zn(L)2(p-bix)] n  (1)

Complex 1 was synthesized solvothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of 3,5-diiodobenzoic acid (0.0112 g, 0.03 mmol), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (p-bix) (0.0071 g, 0.03 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0089 g, 0.03 mmol), NaOH (0.0012 g, 0.03 mmol), and 1 mL of methanol in 6 mL of distilled water at 140 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Subsequent cooling to room temperature yielded colorless block crystals of 1 (75% yield based on zinc). Anal. Calc. for C28H20I4N4O4Zn (1049.45): C, 32.04; H, 1.92; N, 5.34%. Found: C, 32.09; H, 1.96; N. 5.28%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3437 (m), 3112 (m), 1605 (s), 1532 (vs), 1417 (m), 1359 (s), 1247 (m), 1107 (s), 785(m), 721 (m), 653 (w).

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1–8 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1–8 are shown in . For compound 1, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 337 °C. For compounds 2 and 3, the framework collapsed from 340 and 302 °C, respectively. The TG curve of 4 shows that this complex loses its free water molecule between 33 to 128 °C (observed, 1.74%; calculated, 1.79%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 268 °C. For compound 5, the framework collapsed from 329 °C. For compound 6, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 400 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. In the case of compound 7, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 416 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG analysis for crystal samples of 8 shows the framework collapsed from 338 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis and X-ray Powder Diffraction

Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1-8 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1-8 are shown in . For compound 1, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 337 °C. For compounds 2 and 3, the framework collapsed from 340 and 302 °C, respectively. The TG curve of 4 shows that this complex loses its free water molecule between 33 to 128 °C (observed, 1.74%; calculated, 1.79%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 268 °C. For compound 5, the framework collapsed from 329 °C. For compound 6, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature rose to 400 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. In the case of compound 7, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 416 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG analysis for crystal samples of 8 shows the framework collapsed from 338 °C.
